trial_identification.studytitle: A comparison of alcohol delamination and phototherapeutic keratectomy for the treatment of recurrent erosion syndrome.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A comparative clinical trial of alcohol delamination versus phototherapeutic keratectomy for the treatment of recurrent corneal erosions.

interventions.interventions: alcohol delamination (removal of corneal epithelium with 50um of 25% ethyl alcohol for 40 seconds)
interventions.comparator: phototherapeutic keratectomy (excimer laser with 9mm treatment zone and depth of 9um). The treatment time including preparation time and epithelial debridement is less than 10 minutes.

primaryOutcome.outcome: pain score using a numerical rating scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: recurrence of erosions by subjective report
complications by slit lamp examination (eg. haze, infection, scarring) and measurement of visual acuity

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Individuals with symptomatic recurrent corneal erosion syndrome not responding to conservative treatment including regular topical lubrication and a bandage contact lens
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Individuals with a history of previous ocular surgery including any interventional treatment for their recurrent erosion syndrome other than manual epithelial debridement, prior herpetic eye disease, history of other corneal or external eye disease, corneal hypoaesthesia,or a history of diabetes mellitus

trial_design.concealment: Enrolment via the corneal clinic at the Hospital. Patients will only be randomised following recruitment and completion of the consent. Allocation involved contacting a trial coordinator who held a computer generated randomisation plan.

recruitment.hospital: The Royal Victorian Eye and Ear Hospital - East Melbourne

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Royal Victorian Eye and Ear Hospital

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Centre for Eye Research Australia, University of Melbourne

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To compare two different treatment methods of reducing pain and recurrent episodes in individuals with recurrent corneal erosion syndrome, a syndrome characterised by pain, watering and light sensitivity due to episisodic loosening of the surface cells of the eye. The two methods are laser treatment and alcohol treatment to the surface of the eye. It is hypothesised that the two methods are comparable in their effect.
